Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes of Variation in Parid Call Complexity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Human language is the most complex communication system known. However, many non-human animal species also have quite complex communication systems, including non-human primates, whales and dolphins, and even many bird species. The key factors driving such complexity, though, remain largely unknown for both human language and for non-human communication systems. Discovering these factors is crucial to understanding the origin and evolution of such complex behavior, including the origin of language in our own ancestors. The proposed research will use observational and experimental methods to test three key factors proposed to explain vocal communication complexity: social complexity and group size, predation risk, and habitat-induced constraints on sound transmission. The investigators will examine these factors in two common North American bird species that possess complex systems of vocal behavior as well as complex social structures: Carolina chickadees and tufted titmice. The researchers will include their results in their teaching and mentor multiple student researchers in current research methods including Big Data management strategies, and collaborting with supercomputing staff through the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment program associated with the University of Illinois supercomputing facility. Lucas and Freeberg will continue to write about this work for general-audience journals like American Scientist, where they co-authored a 2012 article that has been read by thousands of readers in the U.S. and abroad.

What factors drive the evolution of complex signals? The Social Complexity Hypothesis posits that species or populations forming complex social groups require more complex signaling systems than species or populations that form simpler groups. Although there is increasing evidence to support the Social Complexity Hypothesis, a key limitation is that it is rarely tested against alternative hypotheses. The proposed work tests the Social Complexity Hypothesis against two major alternative hypotheses to explain communicative complexity, using chick-a-dee calls of two avian species of the family Paridae (Carolina chickadees, Poecile carolinensis, and tufted titmice, Baeolophus bicolor): (1) Social Complexity: Individuals in more complex flocks produce calls with greater complexity than individuals in simpler flocks. (2) Habitat Constraints: Individuals in habitats that are more open produce calls with greater complexity than individuals in more closed habitats. (3) Predation Pressure: Individuals in habitats with a greater density or diversity of predators produce calls with greater complexity than individuals facing fewer predators. The hypotheses will be tested with unprecedented resolution through captive flock experiments at the University of Tennessee and University of Florida, data collected on un-manipulated wild flocks, field playback experiments, and observations of flocks before and after scheduled partial forest cuts at the University of Tennessee and Purdue University. The work will increase understanding of the function and mechanisms of complex communicative behavior and provide fundamental information about how complex behavior at the level of the individual emerges from the nature of the social and physical environmental setting in which the individual lives. Parid species are now commonly utilized as a model system for the study of social information use and its fitness consequences in animal communities. This work lays a solid foundation for understanding the nature of parid call complexity and, in turn, the generation of finely tuned information used by many species in fitness-related decision-making in a rapidly changing world. The investigators intend to deposit the data in the University of Tennessee institutional repository, Trace (http://trace.tennessee.edu/), where University of Tennessee Libraries staff will provide appraisal for long-term preservation and stewardship. Trace addresses access, security, preservation, and copyright of deposited research, and ensures that global researchers can find the data, with the assignment of Digital Object Identifiers (DOIs) encouraging proper citation and re-use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Patterns and causes of variation in the vocal complexity of chickadees and titmice

Parids are important species among woodland animals:

Parid is short for birds in family Paridae that includes chickadees and titmice. Parids are chatty, reacting to situations they encounter in daily life with diverse vocalizations. Parids give high-pitched ZZZ calls for flying hawks, chick-a-dee calls for perched owls, and other distinctive calls for hello friend, Im angry, Im flying, I see food, and possibly for my name is (fill the blank).  Extreme vocal complexity of parids provides a model for human language research, but also for interspecies communication. Earlier, we learned that numerous eavesdropping species rely on parid calls to stay alive by avoiding predators, finding food, and traveling safely across habitat gaps. For these reasons, we relate parid behaviors to protective human roles such as town criers or crossing guards and call them keystone community informants.  

Project goals:

We tested three causes of extreme vocal complexity in tufted titmice (Baeolophus bicolor) and Carolina chickadees (Poecile carolinensis) using multiple approaches in FL, TN, and IN (Figure 1). We asked if variation in social complexity, habitat structure, and predator mobbing contexts influences vocal production. We learned that all three factors influence parid language, but that social factors and predation risk are the most important.

Parids perform more vigorously for a diverse audience:

An audience effect is the influence bystanders can have on an individuals behavior (e.g., a bully acts tougher if people watch). Audience effects were defined for single species situations, but our work shows bystanders of other species strongly influence what parids say. Titmice squabble with neighbors using a variety of aggressive calls, but they call more, and more loudly, if larger-bodied birds (e.g., woodpeckers) are watching. In contrast, if titmice fight alone, they are less aggressive, produce fewer calls and use a high-pitched flutter call that is so high in frequency that raptors cant hear them! Therefore, use of this call allows titmice to fight without attracting predators; a function called acoustic crypsis. Whereas, in the presence of larger birds, titmice will fight harder and louder because if a hungry hawk gravitates to a noisy scuffle, like any good predator, it is most likely to attack the largest bird available.

Different habitats generate variation in parid vocal patterns: 

In Florida, parids live in both pinelands, where they are scarce, and hardwood forest where their territories are densely packed. Pineland titmouse territories can be 1 km apart, further than their calls carry. We found pineland birds produce significantly higher diversity of call types than titmice living in high-density hardwoods. Why? Literature suggests high-density parids mimic each others calls to signal local familiarity, which could reduce costly squabbling. Whereas acoustically isolated titmice develop unique family dialects across pinelands that, collectively, sums to higher vocal complexity. Findings reflect a pervasive pattern in nature; isolation by distance fosters greater diversity (from genes to vocal complexity)!

Social dynamics of winter owl-mobbing:  

We studied owl-mobbing aggregations (gatherings of birds scolding perched owls). Among core mobbing species (2 parids, a nuthatch, a woodpecker), mob leadership varies tremendously. In Florida, titmice dominate mobs, arriving faster and more often than other core species. In Indiana, the white-breasted nuthatch (Sitta pusilla) plays this role and titmice hang back. Associated with this is a difference in non-core species attending mobs; > 10 other species commonly attend mobs in FL, but none in IN. We suspect that since nuthatches and woodpeckers are larger than titmice that in FL these species hang back to protect themselves from being predator targets in noisy mobs, forcing titmice to play lead. We are also analyzing recordings to test if species attendance patterns influence the vocal patterns in parid mobbing calls.

The parid twitter feed connects animal communities:

Parid vocal communication is highly advanced compared to most non-human mammals, including primates, perhaps rivaled only by whales and other birds, and provides a valuable source of survival information. In FL alone, close to 50 species of birds and small mammals can interpret titmouse language and actively use their signals in daily life. Across North America and Eurasia, over 40 parid species have similar vocal complexity to our study species. Altogether, this means hundreds; even thousands of species across the Holarctic region may participate in a finely tuned communication network anchored by parids. Indeed, the copious and highly sophisticated language of parids creates a near-global twitter feed worth following!

Species interactions are important in ecological communities, driving many of the ecological services upon which humans ultimately rely. We revealed that parids are highly responsive to the numerous eavesdroppers within their finely tuned communication network, and this emphasizes just how complex and tightly knit are the animal communities around us.
